Award.AwardTitle: Summer Program on Game Theory and Economics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a series of conferences and workshops in game theory and applications of game theory. The conference, follow-on workshops, and lectures are held each summer as a coordinated program designed to bring together a distinguished group of senior scientists from around the globe with junior faculty and graduate students from across the U.S. Topics include new developments in game theory, areas in the intersection between game theory and computer science (such as Computation and Privacy), and applications of game theory to business and public policy. The activities advance science by giving young scholars the opportunity to form new research collaborations and present their work to a distinguished audience.

The topics proposed for the next round of workshops include Auctions, Cooperative Game Theory, High Frequency Finance, Complex Systems and Networks, Equilibrium and Complexity, Algorithmic Mechanism Design, Correlated Equilibrium, Adaptive Learning, Stochastic Games, Computation and Privacy, Macroeconomic Applications of Game Theory, and Memory Complexity in Repeated Games.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcome of the project was to promote intensive interaction between young and established researchers, from all over the world, in the field of Game Theory and its applications, especially to economics. Three International Conferences (more than 250 participants in each one of them), as well as 6 workshops (more than 40 participants in each of them), were held during the entire life of the award. The major cutting-edge results in game theory and its applications were presented and discussed. Many young researchers had an opportunity to present their work and get feedback from senior scholars.

The project contributed to the interaction between scholars, with emphasis on advanced graduate students, junior and senior researchers. The presentations in the conference and workshop sessions fostered a better understanding of the most recent results in the area of Game Theory and its applications in the various fields like: auctions, bargaining, experimental economics, learning and evolution, industrial organization, matching, political economy, law and economics, mechanism design, strategic behavior and the financial crisis, and applications of dynamic games and contracts in macroeconomics.

The project has a strong interdisciplinary orientation. Besides economics and mathematics, the conferences and workshops dealt with issues in evolutionary biology, statistics, computer science, political science, experimental behavior.
